From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

University in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, US

"CMU" redirects here. For other uses, see [CMU (disambiguation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CMU_(disambiguation) "CMU (disambiguation)").

| [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/bb/Carnegie_Mellon_University_seal.svg/250px-Carnegie_Mellon_University_seal.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Carnegie_Mellon_University_seal.svg) |

Carnegie Mellon University

**Carnegie Mellon University** ( **CMU**) is a [private](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Private_university "Private university") [research university](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Research_university "Research university") in [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh "Pittsburgh"), Pennsylvania, United States. The institution was established in 1900 by [Andrew Carnegie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Carnegie "Andrew Carnegie") as the **Carnegie Technical Schools**. In 1912, it became the **Carnegie Institute of Technology** and began granting four-year degrees. In 1967, it became Carnegie Mellon University through its merger with the [Mellon Institute of Industrial Research](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mellon_Institute_of_Industrial_Research "Mellon Institute of Industrial Research"), founded in 1913 by [Andrew Mellon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Mellon "Andrew Mellon") and [Richard B. Mellon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_B._Mellon "Richard B. Mellon") and formerly a part of the [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh").[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-:2-11)

The university consists of seven colleges, including the [College of Engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_College_of_Engineering "Carnegie Mellon College of Engineering"), the [School of Computer Science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_School_of_Computer_Science "Carnegie Mellon School of Computer Science"), the [Dietrich College of Humanities and Social Sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dietrich_College_of_Humanities_and_Social_Sciences "Dietrich College of Humanities and Social Sciences"), and the [Tepper School of Business](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tepper_School_of_Business "Tepper School of Business").[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-12) The university has its main campus located 5 miles (8.0 km) from [downtown Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downtown_Pittsburgh "Downtown Pittsburgh"). It also has over a dozen degree-granting locations on six continents, including campuses in [Qatar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University_in_Qatar "Carnegie Mellon University in Qatar"), [Silicon Valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_Silicon_Valley "Carnegie Mellon Silicon Valley"), and [Kigali, Rwanda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kigali "Kigali") ( [Carnegie Mellon University Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University_Africa "Carnegie Mellon University Africa")) and partnerships with universities nationally and globally.[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-13) Carnegie Mellon enrolls 15,818 students across its multiple campuses from 117 countries and employs more than 1,400 faculty members.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-14) Carnegie Mellon is a member of the [Association of American Universities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_of_American_Universities "Association of American Universities") and is [classified](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Classification_of_Institutions_of_Higher_Education "Carnegie Classification of Institutions of Higher Education") among "R1: Doctoral Universities – Very high research activity".[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-Carnegie_classification-15)

Carnegie Mellon competes in NCAA Division III athletics as a founding member of the [University Athletic Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_Athletic_Association "University Athletic Association"). Carnegie Mellon fields eight men's teams and nine women's teams as the Tartans.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-16) The university's faculty and alumni include 21 [Nobel Prize](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nobel_Prize "Nobel Prize") laureates and 13 [Turing Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turing_Award "Turing Award") winners and have received 142 [Emmy Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emmy_Award "Emmy Award"), 64 [Tony Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Award "Tony Award"), and 13 [Academy Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academy_Awards "Academy Awards").[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-17)

## History

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: History")\]

[![Andrew Carnegie](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Andrew_Carnegie%2C_three-quarter_length_portrait%2C_seated%2C_facing_slightly_left%2C_1913.jpg/250px-Andrew_Carnegie%2C_three-quarter_length_portrait%2C_seated%2C_facing_slightly_left%2C_1913.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Andrew_Carnegie,_three-quarter_length_portrait,_seated,_facing_slightly_left,_1913.jpg)

[Andrew Carnegie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Carnegie "Andrew Carnegie"), founder of the Carnegie Technical Schools.

[![Andrew Mellon](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/AWMellon.jpg/250px-AWMellon.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:AWMellon.jpg)

[Andrew Mellon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Mellon "Andrew Mellon"), co-founder of the Mellon Institute.

The Carnegie Technical Schools were founded in 1900 in [Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh "Pittsburgh")[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-18) by the [Scottish-American](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scottish-American "Scottish-American") industrialist and philanthropist [Andrew Carnegie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Carnegie "Andrew Carnegie"), who wrote "My heart is in the work", when he donated the funds to create the institution. Carnegie's vision was to open a vocational training school for the sons and daughters of working-class Pittsburghers, many of whom worked in his mills. Carnegie was inspired for the design of his school by the [Pratt Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pratt_Institute "Pratt Institute") in [Brooklyn, New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brooklyn,_New_York "Brooklyn, New York"), founded by industrialist [Charles Pratt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Pratt "Charles Pratt") in 1887.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-19) In 1912, the institution changed its name to Carnegie Institute of Technology (CIT) and began offering four-year degrees. During this time, CIT consisted of four constituent schools: the School of Fine and Applied Arts, the School of Apprentices and Journeymen, the School of Science and Technology, and the [Margaret Morrison Carnegie School for Women](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margaret_Morrison_Carnegie_College "Margaret Morrison Carnegie College").

The [Mellon Institute of Industrial Research](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mellon_Institute_of_Industrial_Research "Mellon Institute of Industrial Research") was founded in 1913 by banker and industrialist brothers [Andrew Mellon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Mellon "Andrew Mellon") (who went on to become [U.S. Treasury Secretary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_the_Treasury "United States Secretary of the Treasury")) and [Richard B. Mellon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_B._Mellon "Richard B. Mellon") in honor of their father, [Thomas Mellon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Mellon "Thomas Mellon"), patriarch of the [Mellon family](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mellon_family "Mellon family"). The Institute began as a research organization that performed contract work for government and industry, initially as a department within the [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh"). In 1927, the Mellon Institute was incorporated as an independent nonprofit. In 1937, the Mellon Institute's iconic building was completed on Fifth Avenue.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-20)

In 1967, with support from [Paul Mellon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Mellon "Paul Mellon"), the Carnegie Institute of Technology merged with the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research to become Carnegie Mellon University. In 1973, Carnegie Mellon's coordinate [women's college](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women%27s_colleges_in_the_United_States "Women's colleges in the United States"), the Margaret Morrison Carnegie College, merged its academic programs with the rest of the university.[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-21) The industrial research mission of the Mellon Institute survived the merger as the Carnegie Mellon Research Institute (CMRI) and continued doing work on contract to industry and government. In 2001, CMRI's programs were subsumed by other parts of the university or spun off into autonomous entities.[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-22)

During the 1970s and 1980s, the tenure of president [Richard Cyert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Cyert "Richard Cyert") (1972–1990) witnessed a period of growth and development. The research budget grew from roughly $12 million annually in the early 1970s to more than $110 million in the late 1980s. Researchers in new fields like [robotics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics "Robotics") and [software engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_engineering "Software engineering") helped the university to build its reputation. One example was the introduction of the " [Andrew](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Project "Andrew Project")" computing network in the mid-1980s. This project linking all computers and workstations on campus set the standard for educational computing and established Carnegie Mellon as a technology leader in education and research. On April 24, 1985, _cmu.edu_, Carnegie Mellon's Internet domain, became one of the [first six](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_the_oldest_currently_registered_Internet_domain_names#.edu "List of the oldest currently registered Internet domain names") [.edu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.edu ".edu") domain names.

In the 1990s and into the 2000s, Carnegie Mellon solidified its status among American universities, consistently ranking in the top 25 in the national _[U.S. News & World Report](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._News_%26_World_Report "U.S. News & World Report")_ rankings, and in the top 30 (ranking 28th in 2022) amongst universities worldwide.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-ReferenceA-23)[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-topuniversities.com-24) Carnegie Mellon is distinct in its interdisciplinary approach to research and education. Through the establishment of programs and centers outside the limitations of departments or colleges, the university has established leadership in fields such as [computational finance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_finance "Computational finance"), [information systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_systems "Information systems"), [cognitive sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_sciences "Cognitive sciences"), management, arts management, product design, [behavioral economics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_economics "Behavioral economics"), energy science and economics, [human–computer interaction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human%E2%80%93computer_interaction "Human–computer interaction"), [entertainment technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entertainment_technology "Entertainment technology"), and [decision science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_science "Decision science").

On April 15, 1997, [Jared L. Cohon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jared_Cohon "Jared Cohon"), former dean of the [Yale School of Forestry & Environmental Studies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yale_School_of_Forestry_%26_Environmental_Studies "Yale School of Forestry & Environmental Studies"), was elected president by Carnegie Mellon's board of trustees. During Cohon's presidency, Carnegie Mellon continued its trajectory of innovation and growth. His strategic plan aimed to leverage the university's strengths to benefit society in the areas of [biotechnology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biotechnology "Biotechnology") and [life sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Life_sciences "Life sciences"), information and security technology, [environmental science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_science "Environmental science") and practices, the [fine arts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fine_arts "Fine arts") and [humanities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanities "Humanities"), and business and [public policy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Policy "Policy"). In 2006, following negotiations between President Cohon and South Australian Premier [Mike Rann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Rann "Mike Rann"), CMU opened a campus of the [Heinz College](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_College "Heinz College") in the historic [Torrens Building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torrens_Building "Torrens Building") in [Adelaide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adelaide "Adelaide"), Australia. President Cohon's term ended on June 30, 2013, after which he returned to the faculty at Carnegie Mellon.

On July 1, 2003, Carnegie Mellon launched "Insp!re Innovation", a $1 billion comprehensive fundraising campaign. Half of the campaign goal is intended for the endowment to provide long-lasting support for faculty, students and breakthrough innovations. The campaign brought in a total of $1.19 billion, with $578.5 million going toward Carnegie Mellon's endowment. It also enabled the university to establish 31 endowed professorships, 97 endowed fellowships and 250 endowed scholarships.[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-25)

On September 7, 2011, [William S. Dietrich II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_S._Dietrich_II "William S. Dietrich II"), the former chairman of Dietrich Industries, Inc., a subsidiary of [Worthington Industries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Worthington_Industries "Worthington Industries"), Inc., pledged a gift of $265 million, effective on October 6, 2011, upon his death. In response to this gift, Carnegie Mellon renamed the College of Humanities and Social Sciences as the [Marianna Brown Dietrich College of Humanities and Social Sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dietrich_College_of_Humanities_and_Social_Sciences "Dietrich College of Humanities and Social Sciences") after William Dietrich's mother.[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-26)

On April 23, 2012, New York's Mayor [Michael R. Bloomberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_R._Bloomberg "Michael R. Bloomberg") and [New York University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_University "New York University")'s President [John Sexton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Sexton "John Sexton") announced an agreement between New York City, New York's MTA, and a consortium of academic institutions, and private technology companies that led to the creation in New York of a [Center for Urban Science and Progress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Center_for_Urban_Science_and_Progress "Center for Urban Science and Progress") (CUSP), an applied science research institute composed of a partnership of institutions from around the globe, led by [New York University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_University "New York University") with a consortium of universities including Carnegie Mellon, the [University of Warwick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Warwick "University of Warwick"), the [City University of New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_University_of_New_York "City University of New York"), the [Indian Institute of Technology Bombay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Technology_Bombay "Indian Institute of Technology Bombay"), and the [University of Toronto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Toronto "University of Toronto").

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Cmu-africa-aerial-2021.jpg/250px-Cmu-africa-aerial-2021.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Cmu-africa-aerial-2021.jpg) [Carnegie Mellon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University_Africa "Carnegie Mellon University Africa")'s campus in Kigali, Rwanda.

On February 5, 2013, Carnegie Mellon announced the selection of [Subra Suresh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subra_Suresh "Subra Suresh"), Director of the [National Science Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Science_Foundation "National Science Foundation") and Dean of the [Massachusetts Institute of Technology School of Engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology_School_of_Engineering "Massachusetts Institute of Technology School of Engineering"), as its ninth president effective July 1, 2013.[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-27) Suresh stepped down in June 2017[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-28) and was replaced by [Farnam Jahanian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farnam_Jahanian "Farnam Jahanian"), the university's interim-president and former provost, in March 2018.[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-29)

On October 30, 2019, Carnegie Mellon publicly announced the launch of "Make Possible: The Campaign for Carnegie Mellon University", a campaign which seeks to raise $2 billion to advance the university's priorities, including campus development.[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-30)

On September 8, 2022, Carnegie Mellon announced a $275.7 million partnership with the [Mastercard Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mastercard_Foundation "Mastercard Foundation") to support [Carnegie Mellon University Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University_Africa "Carnegie Mellon University Africa") in [Kigali, Rwanda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kigali "Kigali"). Carnegie Mellon's Kigali campus provides graduate-level study in engineering and artificial intelligence.

On November 6, 2023, Carnegie Mellon Trustee Ray Lane and his wife Stephanie Lane invested $25 million in support of the university's Computational Biology department.[\[31\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-31)

## Campus

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Campus")\]

### Overview

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Overview")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Carnegie_Mellon_University_as_seen_from_the_Cathedral_of_Learning.jpg/250px-Carnegie_Mellon_University_as_seen_from_the_Cathedral_of_Learning.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Carnegie_Mellon_University_as_seen_from_the_Cathedral_of_Learning.jpg) The main campus in [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh "Pittsburgh") as seen from the 36th floor of the [Cathedral of Learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cathedral_of_Learning "Cathedral of Learning") at the [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh"), August 2015

Carnegie Mellon's 157.2 acre (63 ha) main campus is five miles (8 km) from downtown [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh "Pittsburgh"), between [Schenley Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schenley_Park "Schenley Park") and the neighborhoods of [Squirrel Hill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Squirrel_Hill "Squirrel Hill"), [Shadyside](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shadyside_(Pittsburgh) "Shadyside (Pittsburgh)"), and [Oakland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oakland_(Pittsburgh) "Oakland (Pittsburgh)").[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-FR2021-5) Carnegie Mellon is bordered to the west by the campus of the [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh"). Carnegie Mellon owns 81 buildings in the [Oakland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oakland_(Pittsburgh) "Oakland (Pittsburgh)") and [Squirrel Hill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Squirrel_Hill "Squirrel Hill") neighborhoods of Pittsburgh.

For decades, the center of student life on campus was Skibo Hall, the university's student union. Built in the 1950s, Skibo Hall's design was typical of [mid-century modern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mid-century_modern "Mid-century modern") architecture but was poorly equipped to deal with advances in computer and internet connectivity. The original Skibo Hall was razed in the summer of 1994 and replaced by a new student union that is fully Wi-Fi enabled. Known as the University Center, the building was dedicated in 1996. In 2014, Carnegie Mellon re-dedicated the University Center as the Cohon University Center in recognition of the eighth president of the university, [Jared Cohon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jared_Cohon "Jared Cohon").[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-32)

A large grassy area known as "The Cut" forms the backbone of the campus, with a separate grassy area known as "The Mall" running perpendicular. The Cut was formed by filling in a ravine (hence the name) with soil from a nearby hill that was leveled to build the College of Fine Arts building.

The northwestern part of the campus (home to Hamburg Hall, Newell-Simon Hall, Smith Hall, and Gates Hillman Complex) was acquired from the [United States Bureau of Mines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Bureau_of_Mines "United States Bureau of Mines") in the 1980s.

Carnegie Mellon has been purchasing 100% renewable energy for its electricity since 2011.[\[33\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-33)\[ _[additional citation(s) needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Cmu_panorama.jpg/1500px-Cmu_panorama.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Cmu_panorama.jpg "A panoramic view of Carnegie Mellon University's Pittsburgh campus from the College of Fine Arts Lawn. From left to right: College of Fine Arts, Hunt Library, Baker and Porter Hall, Hamerschlag Hall, University of Pittsburgh's Cathedral of Learning (in the background), Wean Hall and Doherty Hall, Purnell Center, and the Cohon University Center. Also visible are \"The Fence\", and the Walking to the Sky sculpture.")

[File:Cmu panorama.jpg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Cmu_panorama.jpg "File:Cmu panorama.jpg")

A panoramic view of Carnegie Mellon University's Pittsburgh campus from the College of Fine Arts Lawn.

From left to right: College of Fine Arts, Hunt Library, Baker and Porter Hall, Hamerschlag Hall, [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh")'s Cathedral of Learning (in the background), Wean Hall and Doherty Hall, Purnell Center, and the Cohon University Center. Also visible are "The Fence", and the _Walking to the Sky_ sculpture.

### Early architecture

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Early architecture")\]

The campus began to take shape in the [Beaux-Arts architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beaux-Arts_architecture "Beaux-Arts architecture") style of [George Carnegie Palmer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Carnegie_Palmer "George Carnegie Palmer") and [Henry Hornbostel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Hornbostel "Henry Hornbostel") of Palmer & Hornbostel, winners of the 1904 competition to design the original institution and later the founder of the [Carnegie Mellon School of Architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_School_of_Architecture "Carnegie Mellon School of Architecture").[\[34\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-34) Most buildings around the university's main campus were originally roofed with green [Ludowici](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ludowici_Roof_Tile "Ludowici Roof Tile") [Spanish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pantile "Pantile") tile.[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-35)

There was little change to the campus between the [first](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_I "World War I") and [second World War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"). A 1938 master plan by Githens and [Keally](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francis_Keally "Francis Keally") suggested acquisition of new land along [Forbes Avenue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes_Avenue "Forbes Avenue"), but the plan was not fully implemented. The period starting with the construction of the Hall of the Arts building (former home of the Graduate School of Industrial Administration) in 1952 and ending with Wean Hall in 1971 saw the institutional change from Carnegie Institute of Technology to Carnegie Mellon University. Around this time an expanding student population demanded improved facilities for student life, athletics and libraries. The campus expanded to Forbes Avenue from its original land along [Schenley Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schenley_Park "Schenley Park").

### Mid-20th century

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Mid-20th century")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Carnegie_Mellon_Hamerschlag_Hall_and_Scott_Hall.jpg/250px-Carnegie_Mellon_Hamerschlag_Hall_and_Scott_Hall.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Carnegie_Mellon_Hamerschlag_Hall_and_Scott_Hall.jpg) Hamerschlag, Roberts, and Scott Halls are three of the teaching facilities of the [College of Engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_College_of_Engineering "Carnegie Mellon College of Engineering")

The buildings of this era reflected contemporary architectural styles. The [International Style](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Style_(architecture) "International Style (architecture)"), with its rejection of historical tradition and its emphases on functionalism and expression of structure, had been in vogue in European settings since the 1930s. It came late to the Carnegie Mellon campus because of the hiatus in building activity and a general reluctance among American universities to abandon historical styles. By the 1960s, the International Style was adopted to accomplish needed expansion quickly and affordably with the swelling of student ranks in the aftermath of the [GI Bill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GI_Bill "GI Bill") in 1944. Each building was a unique architectural statement that may have acknowledged the existing campus in its placement, but not in its form or materials.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Wean_hall.jpg/250px-Wean_hall.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Wean_hall.jpg) Wean Hall, home of the world's first internet-enabled soda vending machine.[\[36\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-36)

Starting in the 1990s the university built a new university center (Cohon University Center), theater and drama building (Purnell Center for the Arts), business school building ( [Tepper School of Business](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tepper_School_of_Business "Tepper School of Business")), and several dormitories.

### 2000s

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: 2000s")\]

Baker Hall was renovated in the early 2000s, and new chemistry labs were established in Doherty Hall soon after. Several computer science buildings, such as [Newell-Simon Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newell_Simon_Hall "Newell Simon Hall"), also were established, renovated or renamed in the early 2000s.

In 2006, Carnegie Mellon Trustee Jill Gansman Kraus donated the 80-foot (24 m)-tall sculpture _[Walking to the Sky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walking_to_the_Sky "Walking to the Sky")_, which was placed on the lawn facing Forbes Avenue between the Cohon University Center and Warner Hall. The sculpture was controversial for its placement, the general lack of input from the campus community, and its (lack of) aesthetic appeal.[\[37\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-37)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Gates-Hillman_Complex_at_Carnegie_Mellon_University_2.jpg/500px-Gates-Hillman_Complex_at_Carnegie_Mellon_University_2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Gates-Hillman_Complex_at_Carnegie_Mellon_University_2.jpg) The Gates Hillman Complex, which houses the [School of Computer Science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_School_of_Computer_Science "Carnegie Mellon School of Computer Science").[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Carnegie_Mellon_Cohon_University_Center_2016.jpg/250px-Carnegie_Mellon_Cohon_University_Center_2016.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Carnegie_Mellon_Cohon_University_Center_2016.jpg) Cohon University Center, which contains an indoor swimming pool, bookstore, student club facilities, gym, and cafeteria.

The Gates Hillman Complex opened for occupancy on August 7, 2009.[\[38\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-38) It sits on a 5.6-acre (2.3 ha) site on the university's West Campus, surrounded by Cyert Hall, the Purnell Center for the Arts, Doherty Hall, Newell-Simon Hall, Smith Hall, [Hamburg Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Building,_U.S._Bureau_of_Mines "Main Building, U.S. Bureau of Mines"), and the Robert Mehrabian Collaborative Innovation Center. It contains 318 offices as well as labs, [computer clusters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_cluster "Computer cluster"), lecture halls, classrooms and a 255-seat auditorium. The Gates Hillman Complex was made possible by a $20 million lead gift from the [Gates Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gates_Foundation "Gates Foundation") and an additional $10 million grant from the [Henry L. Hillman Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Hillman "Henry Hillman"). The Gates Hillman Complex and the Purnell Center for the Arts are connected by the [Randy Pausch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randy_Pausch "Randy Pausch") Memorial Footbridge.[\[39\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-39)

In September 2012, Carnegie Mellon announced the construction of the Sherman and Joyce Bowie Scott Hall on the Pittsburgh campus. The building is situated between Hamerschlag Hall, Roberts Hall, and Wean Hall and houses the Wilton E. Scott Institute for Energy Innovation, Bertucci Nanotechnology Lab, Engineering Research Accelerator (formerly known as the Institute for Complex Engineered Systems), Disruptive Health Technologies Institute, and the Department of Biomedical Engineering.[\[40\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-40) In November 2013, Carnegie Mellon announced a $67 million gift from [David Tepper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Tepper "David Tepper"), who previously donated $56 million, to develop the Tepper Quadrangle on the north campus. The Tepper Quad includes a new Tepper School of Business facility across [Forbes Avenue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes_Avenue "Forbes Avenue") from a renovated and expanded Hamburg Hall (home to Heinz College)[\[41\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-Heinz_Endowments_Gift-41) as well as other university-wide buildings and a welcome center to serve as a public gateway to the university.[\[42\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-42)

In April 2015, Carnegie Mellon, in collaboration with [Jones Lang LaSalle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jones_Lang_LaSalle "Jones Lang LaSalle"), announced the planning of a second office space structure, alongside the Robert Mehrabian Collaborative Innovation Center, an upscale and full-service hotel, and retail and dining development along Forbes Avenue. This complex will connect to the Tepper Quadrangle, the Heinz College, the Tata Consultancy Services Building, and the Gates-Hillman Center to create an innovation corridor on the university campus. The effort is intended to continue to attract major corporate partnerships to create opportunities for research, teaching, and employment with students and faculty.[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-43)

Alongside the Tepper Quad and Hamburg Hall, Carnegie Mellon finished construction in 2020 on TCS Hall, an innovation center made possible with a $35 million gift from [Tata Consultancy Services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tata_Consultancy_Services "Tata Consultancy Services").[\[44\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-44) Carnegie Mellon announced plans to collaborate with [Emerald Cloud Lab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emerald_Cloud_Lab "Emerald Cloud Lab") to construct the world's first cloud lab in a university setting. The Carnegie Mellon University Cloud Lab was planned to be completed by the spring of 2023. Carnegie Mellon also planned to construct a new mechanical engineering building by fall 2023 (Scaife Hall), a new $105 million athletics center by fall 2024 (Highmark Center for Health, Wellness and Athletics), a $210 million Science Futures Building (R.K. Mellon Hall of Sciences) by 2026,[\[45\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-45) as well as a Robotics Innovation Center at Hazelwood Green, along with new dormitories and other buildings.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-46)

On April 12, 2024, Carnegie Mellon broke ground for construction of its new Richard King Mellon Hall of Sciences, a 338,900 square-foot addition to its campus.[\[47\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-47)

## Organization

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Organization")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/School_of_design.jpg/250px-School_of_design.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:School_of_design.jpg) Margaret Morrison Carnegie Hall, home of the [Carnegie Mellon School of Architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_School_of_Architecture "Carnegie Mellon School of Architecture") and [Carnegie Mellon School of Design](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_School_of_Design "Carnegie Mellon School of Design")

The [College of Engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_College_of_Engineering "Carnegie Mellon College of Engineering") includes seven engineering departments ( [Biomedical Engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biomedical_Engineering "Biomedical Engineering"), [Chemical Engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemical_Engineering "Chemical Engineering"), [Civil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_Engineering "Civil Engineering") and [Environmental Engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_Engineering "Environmental Engineering"), [Electrical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrical_Engineering "Electrical Engineering") and [Computer Engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_Engineering "Computer Engineering"), [Engineering and Public Policy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Engineering_and_Public_Policy "Engineering and Public Policy"), [Mechanical Engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mechanical_Engineering "Mechanical Engineering"), and [Materials Science and Engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Materials_science "Materials science")), two interdisciplinary institutes (the [Information Networking Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_Networking_Institute "Information Networking Institute") and the [Integrated Innovation Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrated_Innovation_Institute "Integrated Innovation Institute")), and the Engineering Research Accelerator.

The [College of Fine Arts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_College_of_Fine_Arts "Carnegie Mellon College of Fine Arts") is one of the oldest colleges of fine arts in the United States, and today it is a federation of five distinct schools: [The School of Architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_School_of_Architecture "Carnegie Mellon School of Architecture"), [The School of Music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_School_of_Music "Carnegie Mellon School of Music"), [The School of Design](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_School_of_Design "Carnegie Mellon School of Design"), [The School of Drama](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_School_of_Drama "Carnegie Mellon School of Drama"), and [The School of Art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_School_of_Art "Carnegie Mellon School of Art").[\[48\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-48)[\[49\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-49)[\[50\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-50) The college shares research projects, interdisciplinary centers and educational programs with other units across the university.[\[51\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-51) The College of Fine Arts runs master's programs in Arts Management and Entertainment Industry Management with the Heinz College, as well as interdisciplinary undergraduate programs with the [Dietrich College of Humanities and Social Sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dietrich_College_of_Humanities_and_Social_Sciences "Dietrich College of Humanities and Social Sciences") (BHA), [Mellon College of Science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mellon_College_of_Science "Mellon College of Science") (BSA), the [School of Computer Science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_School_of_Computer_Science "Carnegie Mellon School of Computer Science") (BCSA), and the [College of Engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_College_of_Engineering "Carnegie Mellon College of Engineering") (BESA).[\[52\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-52)

The [Dietrich College of Humanities and Social Sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dietrich_College_of_Humanities_and_Social_Sciences "Dietrich College of Humanities and Social Sciences") is the university's liberal arts college and emphasizes the study of the human condition through rigorous analysis and technology. Departments include [English](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_studies "English studies"), [History](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History "History"), [Modern Languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_Languages "Modern Languages"), [Philosophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy "Philosophy"), [Psychology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychology "Psychology"), [Social and Decision Sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_and_Decision_Sciences "Social and Decision Sciences"), and [Statistics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistics "Statistics") as well as an Institute for Politics and Strategy. The college also offers undergraduate degree programs in [Information Systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_systems "Information systems"), Economics (jointly with the Tepper School of Business), and the Bachelor of Humanities and Arts (BHA) with the [College of Fine Arts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_College_of_Fine_Arts "Carnegie Mellon College of Fine Arts").[\[53\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-53)

The [H. John Heinz III College of Information Systems and Public Policy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_College "Heinz College") offers top-ranked master's degrees in [Public Policy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Policy "Public Policy") and Management, Health Care Policy and Management, Medical Management, [Public Management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Management "Public Management"), [Information Systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_Systems "Information Systems") and Management, Information Technology, and Information Security Policy and Management. The Heinz College also runs master's programs in Arts Management and Entertainment Industry Management with the College of Fine Arts. Heinz College consists of the School of Information Systems & Management and the School of Public Policy & Management. It also offers several PhD and executive education programs.

The [Mellon College of Science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mellon_College_of_Science "Mellon College of Science") has four departments: [Biological Sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_Sciences "Biological Sciences"), [Chemistry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemistry "Chemistry"), [Mathematical Sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_Sciences "Mathematical Sciences"), and [Physics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physics "Physics"). The college is expanding efforts in [neuroscience](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuroscience "Neuroscience"), [green chemistry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_chemistry "Green chemistry"), [bioinformatics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bioinformatics "Bioinformatics"), [computational biology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_biology "Computational biology"), [nanotechnology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanotechnology "Nanotechnology"), [computational finance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_finance "Computational finance"), cosmology, sensor research, and biological physics. It also offers an undergraduate Bachelor of Science and Arts (BSA) degree in conjunction with the [College of Fine Arts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_College_of_Fine_Arts "Carnegie Mellon College of Fine Arts").[\[54\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-54)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Interior_of_Gates_Hillman_Center.jpg/250px-Interior_of_Gates_Hillman_Center.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Interior_of_Gates_Hillman_Center.jpg) Inside the Gates-Hillman Complex of the School of Computer Science.

The [School of Computer Science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_School_of_Computer_Science "Carnegie Mellon School of Computer Science"): Carnegie Mellon helped define, and continually redefines, the field of [computer science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_science "Computer science"). The School of Computer Science is recognized internationally as one of the top schools for computer science[\[55\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-55) and has been consistently ranked the best in the country. The School of Computer Science includes seven departments: the Computer Science Department, [Ray and Stephanie Lane Computational Biology Department](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_Biology_Department "Computational Biology Department"), [Robotics Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics_Institute "Robotics Institute"), Machine Learning Department, the [Human–Computer Interaction Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human%E2%80%93Computer_Interaction_Institute "Human–Computer Interaction Institute"), the [Language Technologies Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_Technologies_Institute "Language Technologies Institute"), and the Software and Societal Systems Department (S3D). It additionally offers the undergraduate Bachelor of Computer Science and Arts (BCSA) degree in conjunction with the [College of Fine Arts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_College_of_Fine_Arts "Carnegie Mellon College of Fine Arts").[\[56\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-56)

The [Tepper School of Business](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tepper_School_of_Business "Tepper School of Business") (formerly the Graduate School of Industrial Administration) offers undergraduate programs in [Business Administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Business_Administration "Business Administration") and [Economics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economics "Economics") (the latter jointly with the Dietrich College), master's degrees in Business Administration ( [MBA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Master_of_Business_Administration "Master of Business Administration")), Product Management (MSPM) and joint degrees in [Computational Finance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_Finance "Computational Finance") (MSCF) with the Dietrich College of Humanities and Social Sciences, the Mellon College of Science, the Heinz College, and the School of Computer Science. In addition, joint degrees are offered with Civil and Environmental Engineering and the Heinz College. The Tepper School also offers doctoral degrees in several areas and presents a number of [executive education](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executive_education "Executive education") programs. Following a $67 million donation from alumnus [David A. Tepper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Tepper "David Tepper") in 2013, the university expanded the undergraduate business program and named the school after him. In summer of 2015, a new curriculum was formally instated.[\[57\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-57)

In addition to research and academic institutions, the university hosts several other educationally driven programs. The [Pennsylvania Governor's School for the Sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pennsylvania_Governor%27s_School_for_the_Sciences "Pennsylvania Governor's School for the Sciences"), a state-funded summer program that aims to foster interest in science amongst gifted high school students is run on campus every summer. The university also runs Carnegie Mellon [Pre-College](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University_Pre-College_Program&action=edit&redlink=1 "Carnegie Mellon University Pre-College Program (page does not exist)"), a six-week residential program for rising juniors and seniors in high school and the Summer Academy for Math and Science (SAMS), a free-of-charge STEM immersion program for students from underrepresented backgrounds. The Cyert Center for Early Education is a child care center for Carnegie Mellon faculty and staff, as well as an observational setting for students in child development courses. Carnegie Mellon also developed the Open Learning Initiative which provides free courses online in a variety of fields to students globally.

### IDeATe

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: IDeATe")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Entertainment_Technology_Center%2C_Carnegie_Mellon_University.jpg/250px-Entertainment_Technology_Center%2C_Carnegie_Mellon_University.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Entertainment_Technology_Center,_Carnegie_Mellon_University.jpg) Carnegie Mellon's [Entertainment Technology Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entertainment_Technology_Center "Entertainment Technology Center")

Carnegie Mellon also runs the Integrative Design, Arts, and Technology (IDeATe) Network to provide university-wide arts and technology education to students from every college. IDeATe allows students to take minors or concentrations in Animation and Special Effects, Entrepreneurship for Creative Industries, Game Design, Intelligent Environments, Learning Media, Media Design, Physical Computing, and Sound Design. IDeAte will also offer graduate master's degrees in Emerging Media, Game Design, Integrative Innovation for Products and Services, Computational Data Science, Urban Design, and Production Technology and Management. IDeATe also manages the [Entertainment Technology Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entertainment_Technology_Center "Entertainment Technology Center") (ETC) in conjunction with the School of Computer Science and the College of Fine Arts. Each master's degree program has an option to study in the CMU Integrative Media Program (IMP) at [Steiner Studios](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steiner_Studios "Steiner Studios") in [New York City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"). IDeATe Network will be based on the Pittsburgh campus upon the development of recently acquired property on [Forbes Avenue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes_Avenue "Forbes Avenue") west of [Junction Hollow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Junction_Hollow "Junction Hollow").[\[58\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-58)

## Academics

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Academics")\]

### Rankings

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Rankings")\]

| [Academic rankings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/College_and_university_rankings_in_the_United_States "College and university rankings in the United States") |

Nationally, _[U.S. News & World Report](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._News_%26_World_Report "U.S. News & World Report")_ placed Carnegie Mellon in a tie with [Washington University in St. Louis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_University_in_St._Louis "Washington University in St. Louis") and the [University of Michigan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Michigan "University of Michigan") for 21st place among American research universities in their 2024-2025 rankings.[\[68\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-68) Many of its graduate programs have been ranked in national and international surveys. In 2022, _U.S. News_ ranked Carnegie Mellon as having 23 graduate programs in the Top 10 nationwide and 16 in the Top 5 nationwide.,[\[69\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-69) including three programs ranked first: Artificial Intelligence, Programming Languages, and Information and Technology Management. In particular, the [CMU School of Computer Science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_School_of_Computer_Science "Carnegie Mellon School of Computer Science") has been consistently ranked the best in the nation, tied with [MIT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology "Massachusetts Institute of Technology"), [Stanford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanford_University "Stanford University"), and [UC Berkeley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_California,_Berkeley "University of California, Berkeley").[\[70\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-70)

Globally, Carnegie Mellon is ranked 28th by _[Times Higher Education](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Times_Higher_Education "Times Higher Education")_ and 52nd by _[QS World University Rankings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings "QS World University Rankings")_.

Carnegie Mellon was named one of the "New [Ivies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivy_League "Ivy League")" by _[Newsweek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newsweek "Newsweek")_.[\[71\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-71) In 2010, _[The Wall Street Journal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal "The Wall Street Journal")_ ranked Carnegie Mellon 1st in computer science, 4th in finance, 10th overall, and 21st in engineering according to job recruiters.[\[72\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-72) Carnegie Mellon ranks thirteenth among "Best Colleges By Salary Potential (Bachelor's Only)" in the United States according to _[PayScale](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PayScale "PayScale")_'s 2016–17 study.[\[73\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-73) In 2024, Carnegie Mellon's [Tepper School of Business](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tepper_School_of_Business "Tepper School of Business") placed 9th in an [annual ranking](https://www.bloomberg.com/business-schools/regions/us/) of U.S. business schools by _[Bloomberg Businessweek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bloomberg_Businessweek "Bloomberg Businessweek")_.[\[74\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-74)

In 2016, _[The Hollywood Reporter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter "The Hollywood Reporter")_ ranked the School of Drama 3rd in the world among undergraduate drama schools.[\[75\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-75) In 2015, the same publication ranked the MFA program at the School of Drama 5th in the world.[\[76\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-76)

Carnegie Mellon's [Dietrich College of Humanities and Social Sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dietrich_College_of_Humanities_and_Social_Sciences "Dietrich College of Humanities and Social Sciences") was ranked 55th for social sciences and 60th for humanities in the world by _[Times Higher Education](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Times_Higher_Education "Times Higher Education")_ for 2020.[\[77\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-77)[\[78\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-78) Dietrich College is also ranked 20th for social sciences among Shanghai Jiao Tong University's world's top 100 universities.[\[79\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-79)

Carnegie Mellon is one of 66 elected members of the [Association of American Universities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_of_American_Universities "Association of American Universities") and one of 29 members (one of 13 American members) of the [World Economic Forum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Economic_Forum "World Economic Forum") [Global University Leaders Forum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_University_Leaders_Forum "Global University Leaders Forum").[\[80\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-80)

### Admissions

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Admissions")\]

_U.S. News & World Report_ rates admission to Carnegie Mellon as "most selective".[\[89\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-89) For the class of 2026 (enrolling in fall 2022), Carnegie Mellon received 34,261 applications and admitted approximately 3,873 (11%), with 1,736 enrolling.[\[90\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-90) The acceptance rates of the individual colleges and programs range from [Carnegie Mellon School of Architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_School_of_Architecture "Carnegie Mellon School of Architecture")'s 30% to [Carnegie Mellon School of Drama](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_School_of_Drama "Carnegie Mellon School of Drama")'s 3%.[\[91\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-Facts-91) The largest college, in terms of the class of 2025 enrollment, is the College of Engineering with 499 students, followed by the Dietrich College of Humanities and Social Sciences with 391, and the Mellon College of Science with 266.[\[92\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-92) The smallest college is the School of Design, with 34.[\[91\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-Facts-91) The middle 50% range of [SAT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAT "SAT") scores of enrolled freshmen was 720-770 for reading and writing, and 770-800 for math, while the middle 50% range of the [ACT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ACT_(test) "ACT (test)") composite score was 34–35.[\[93\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-93) The university is [need-blind](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Need-blind "Need-blind") for domestic applicants.[\[94\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-94) The class of 2026 enrolled students from 46 U.S. states and 42 countries.[\[91\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-Facts-91) Undergraduate tuition for 2023-2024 is $62,260, and room and board is $17,468.[\[95\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-95)

### Research

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Research")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Posner_1.jpg/250px-Posner_1.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Posner_1.jpg) Posner Hall, former home of the [Tepper School of Business](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tepper_School_of_Business "Tepper School of Business")

CMU is [classified](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Classification_of_Institutions_of_Higher_Education "Carnegie Classification of Institutions of Higher Education") among "R1: Doctoral Universities – Very High Research Activity".[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-Carnegie_classification-15) For the 2021 fiscal year, the university spent $402 million on research. The primary recipients of this funding were the School of Computer Science ($100.3 million), the [Software Engineering Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_Engineering_Institute "Software Engineering Institute") ($71.7 million), the College of Engineering ($48.5 million), and the Mellon College of Science ($47.7 million). The research money comes largely from federal sources, with a federal investment of $234.9 million in 2021. The federal agencies that invest the most money include the [National Science Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Science_Foundation "National Science Foundation") and the [Department of Defense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense "United States Department of Defense"), which contributed $70.5 million and $90.4 million in 2021, respectively.[\[96\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-96)

The recognition of Carnegie Mellon as one of the best research facilities in the nation has a long history. As early as the 1987 federal budget, CMU was ranked as third in the amount of federal research funds received with $41.5 million, with only MIT and Johns Hopkins receiving more research funds from the Department of Defense.[\[97\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-97)

The [Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Supercomputing_Center "Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center") (PSC) is a joint effort between Carnegie Mellon, [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh"), and [Westinghouse Electric Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westinghouse_Electric_Company "Westinghouse Electric Company"). PSC was founded in 1986 by its two scientific directors, Ralph Roskies of the University of Pittsburgh and Michael Levine of Carnegie Mellon. PSC is a leading partner in the [TeraGrid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TeraGrid "TeraGrid"), the National Science Foundation's cyberinfrastructure program.[\[98\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-98)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Scarab_Lunar_Rover.jpg/250px-Scarab_Lunar_Rover.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Scarab_Lunar_Rover.jpg) The [Scarab lunar rover](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scarab_(lunar_rover) "Scarab (lunar rover)") is being developed by the RI.

The Neuroscience Institute (NI) is a university-wide research institute that was founded in 2018
[\[99\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-99)[\[100\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-100)[\[101\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-101) as a successor to an earlier effort, known as Brainhub.
[\[102\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-102)[\[103\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-103)
Combining research in [computer science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_science "Computer science"), [engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Engineering "Engineering"), [machine learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning "Machine learning"), [statistics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistics "Statistics"), and [cognitive science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_science "Cognitive science") with basic [neuroscience](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuroscience "Neuroscience"), NI aims to promote research that will improve the human condition. Devices developed by the institute have been designed to enable communication for locked-in patients,[\[104\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-104) treatments for [Parkinson's disease](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parkinson%27s_disease "Parkinson's disease"),[\[105\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-105) improved [brain imaging](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brain_imaging "Brain imaging") technology using [artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence "Artificial intelligence"),[\[106\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-106) and [electrodes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrode "Electrode") that work with coarse, curly hair.[\[107\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-107) NI includes over 30 faculty and 100 trainees from four colleges and oversees two [PhD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PhD "PhD") programs (the Program in Neural Computation and the Program in Systems Neuroscience) that have received support from the [National Institutes of Health](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Institutes_of_Health "National Institutes of Health").
[\[108\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-108)[\[109\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-109) Numerous philanthropic gifts help support NI research.
[\[110\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-110)[\[111\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-111)[\[112\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-112)[\[113\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-113) NI also provides direct administrative and monetary support for the Center for Neural Basis of Cognition, a long-running collaboration with the [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh").[\[114\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-114)[\[115\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-115)

The [Robotics Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics_Institute "Robotics Institute") (RI) is a division of the School of Computer Science and considered to be one of the leading centers of robotics research in the world. The Field Robotics Center (FRC) has developed a number of significant robots, including [Sandstorm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandstorm_(vehicle) "Sandstorm (vehicle)") and [H1ghlander](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H1ghlander "H1ghlander"), which finished second and third in the [DARPA Grand Challenge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DARPA_Grand_Challenge "DARPA Grand Challenge"), and Boss, which won the [DARPA Urban Challenge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DARPA_Urban_Challenge "DARPA Urban Challenge"). The Robotics Institute has partnered with a spinoff company, [Astrobotic Technology Inc.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astrobotic_Technology "Astrobotic Technology"), to land a CMU robot on the moon by 2016 in pursuit of the Google Lunar XPrize. The robot, known as Andy, is designed to explore lunar pits, which might include entrances to caves.[\[116\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-116) The RI is primarily sited at Carnegie Mellon's main campus in Newell-Simon hall.[\[117\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-117)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Software_Engineering_Institute%2C_Oakland%2C_Pittsburgh%2C_2019-09-30.jpg/250px-Software_Engineering_Institute%2C_Oakland%2C_Pittsburgh%2C_2019-09-30.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Software_Engineering_Institute,_Oakland,_Pittsburgh,_2019-09-30.jpg) The [Software Engineering Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_Engineering_Institute "Software Engineering Institute") building on Fifth Avenue.

The [Software Engineering Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_Engineering_Institute "Software Engineering Institute") (SEI) is a [federally funded research and development center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federally_funded_research_and_development_center "Federally funded research and development center") sponsored by the U.S. Department of Defense and operated by Carnegie Mellon, with offices in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA and Arlington, Virginia. The SEI publishes books on [software engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_engineering "Software engineering") for industry, government and military applications and practices. The organization is known for its [Capability Maturity Model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capability_Maturity_Model "Capability Maturity Model")[\[118\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-CMM-118)[\[119\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-119)
(CMM) and [Capability Maturity Model Integration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capability_Maturity_Model_Integration "Capability Maturity Model Integration") (CMMI), which identify essential elements of effective system and software engineering processes and can be used to rate the level of an organization's capability for producing quality systems. The SEI is also the home of [CERT/CC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CERT_Coordination_Center "CERT Coordination Center"), the federally funded computer security organization. The CERT Program's primary goals are to support secure requirements and development of computer systems and ensure that appropriate technology and systems management practices are used to resist attacks on networked systems and to limit damage and ensure continuity of critical services subsequent to attacks, accidents, or failures.[\[120\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-120)

The [Human–Computer Interaction Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human%E2%80%93Computer_Interaction_Institute "Human–Computer Interaction Institute") (HCII) is a division of the School of Computer Science and is considered one of the leading centers of [human–computer interaction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human%E2%80%93computer_interaction "Human–computer interaction") research, integrating computer science, design, social science, and learning science.[\[121\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-121) Such interdisciplinary collaboration is the hallmark of research done throughout the university.

The [Language Technologies Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_Technologies_Institute "Language Technologies Institute") (LTI) is another unit of the School of Computer Science and is famous for being one of the leading research centers in the area of [language technologies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_technologies "Language technologies"). The primary research focus of the institute is on [machine translation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_translation "Machine translation"), [speech recognition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speech_recognition "Speech recognition"), [speech synthesis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speech_synthesis "Speech synthesis"), [information retrieval](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_retrieval "Information retrieval"), [parsing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsing "Parsing") and [information extraction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_extraction "Information extraction").[\[122\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-122) Until 1996, the institute existed as the Center for Machine Translation that was established in 1986. From 1996 onwards, it started awarding graduate degrees and the name was changed to Language Technologies Institute.

The [Ray and Stephanie Lane Computational Biology Department](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_Biology_Department "Computational Biology Department"), one of the seven departments in the [School of Computer Science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_School_of_Computer_Science "Carnegie Mellon School of Computer Science"), was established in 2007 (as Lane Center for Computational Biology), officially became a department within the School of Computer Science in 2009, and named the Ray and Stephanie Lane Computational Biology Department in 2023. The department is the leader in developing computational methodologies to advance biomedical research.

Carnegie Mellon is also home to the [Carnegie School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_School "Carnegie School") of management and economics. This intellectual school grew out of the [Tepper School of Business](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tepper_School_of_Business "Tepper School of Business") in the 1950s and 1960s and focused on the intersection of behavioralistm and management. Several management theories, most notably [bounded rationality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bounded_rationality "Bounded rationality") and the behavioral [theory of the firm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theory_of_the_firm "Theory of the firm"), were established by Carnegie School management scientists and economists.

Carnegie Mellon also develops cross-disciplinary and university-wide institutes and initiatives to take advantage of strengths in various colleges and departments and develop solutions in critical social and technical problems. To date, these have included the [Cylab Security and Privacy Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_CyLab "Carnegie Mellon CyLab"), the Wilton E. Scott Institute for Energy Innovation, the [Neuroscience Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_Neuroscience_Institute&action=edit&redlink=1 "Carnegie Mellon Neuroscience Institute (page does not exist)"), the Simon Initiative, and the Disruptive Healthcare Technology Institute.

Carnegie Mellon has made a concerted effort to attract corporate research labs, offices, and partnerships to the Pittsburgh campus. [Apple Inc.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Inc. "Apple Inc."), [Intel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intel "Intel"), [Google](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google "Google"), [Microsoft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft"), [Disney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disney "Disney"), [Facebook](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facebook "Facebook"), [IBM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM "IBM"), [General Motors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Motors "General Motors"), [Bombardier Inc.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bombardier_Inc. "Bombardier Inc."), [Yahoo!](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yahoo! "Yahoo!"), [Uber](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uber "Uber"), [Tata Consultancy Services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tata_Consultancy_Services "Tata Consultancy Services"), [Ansys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ansys "Ansys"), [Boeing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing "Boeing"), [Robert Bosch GmbH](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Bosch_GmbH "Robert Bosch GmbH"), and the [Rand Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rand_Corporation "Rand Corporation") have established a presence on or near campus. In collaboration with Intel, Carnegie Mellon has pioneered research into [claytronics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claytronics "Claytronics").[\[123\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-123)

### International activities

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: International activities")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Steps_in_Carnegie_Mellon_University_campus_in_Qatar.jpg/250px-Steps_in_Carnegie_Mellon_University_campus_in_Qatar.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Steps_in_Carnegie_Mellon_University_campus_in_Qatar.jpg) Part of Carnegie Mellon's Education City campus in Qatar.

In addition to its Pittsburgh campus, Carnegie Mellon has a branch campus in the Middle East, [Carnegie Mellon University in Qatar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University_in_Qatar "Carnegie Mellon University in Qatar"), which offers a full undergraduate curriculum with degree programs in computer science, business administration, biology, computational biology, and information systems. The campus is located in [Doha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doha "Doha")'s [Education City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Education_City "Education City") which is home to multiple other U.S. universities all of which are funded by the [Qatar Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qatar_Foundation "Qatar Foundation"). The [Qatari](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qatar "Qatar") campus has been the subject of controversy, as Islamic cultural values and laws in Qatar differ greatly from the core values of Carnegie Mellon.[\[124\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-washingtonpost.com-124) Additionally, Carnegie Mellon and other U.S. universities in Education City have been criticized for being essentially complicit in Qatar's corruption, connections with [Hamas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamas "Hamas") and their questionable [human rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_rights "Human rights") record by continuing to operate there.[\[124\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-washingtonpost.com-124)[\[125\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-125)[\[126\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-126)[\[127\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-127)

It also has graduate-level extension campuses in [Mountain View, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_Silicon_Valley "Carnegie Mellon Silicon Valley") in the heart of [Silicon Valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silicon_Valley "Silicon Valley") (offering masters programs in [Software Engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_engineering "Software engineering") and Software Management). The [Tepper School of Business](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tepper_School_of_Business "Tepper School of Business") maintains a satellite center in downtown [Manhattan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan") and the Heinz College maintains one in [Adelaide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adelaide "Adelaide"), Australia. The [Heinz College](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_College "Heinz College"), the Institute for Politics and Strategy, and the Department of [Engineering and Public Policy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Engineering_and_Public_Policy "Engineering and Public Policy") host centers in [Washington, D.C.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.") as part of degree programs, research, and government affairs initiatives as well as being a part of the [University of California, Washington Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_California,_Washington_Center "University of California, Washington Center"). Carnegie Mellon also established the Integrative Media Program at [Steiner Studios](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steiner_Studios "Steiner Studios") in [Brooklyn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brooklyn "Brooklyn"), New York. Carnegie Mellon also maintains the Carnegie Mellon Los Angeles Center in [North Hollywood, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Hollywood,_California "North Hollywood, California") where students in the Master of Entertainment Industry Management program are required to relocate to Los Angeles in their second year and attend classes at this facility.

Carnegie Mellon's [Information Networking Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_Networking_Institute "Information Networking Institute") offers graduate programs in [Athens, Greece](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athens,_Greece "Athens, Greece") and [Kobe, Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kobe,_Japan "Kobe, Japan"), in collaboration with [Athens Information Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Athens_Information_Technology&action=edit&redlink=1 "Athens Information Technology (page does not exist)") and the Hyogo Institute of Information Education Foundation, respectively. In the fall of 2007, the cities of [Aveiro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aveiro,_Portugal "Aveiro, Portugal") and [Lisbon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lisbon "Lisbon"), Portugal were added to the [Information Networking Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_Networking_Institute "Information Networking Institute")'s remote locations. The Software and Societal Systems Department (S3D) offers graduate programs in [Coimbra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coimbra,_Portugal "Coimbra, Portugal"), Portugal. The Entertainment Technology Center offers graduate programs in Portugal, Japan, and Singapore. The [Human–Computer Interaction Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human%E2%80%93Computer_Interaction_Institute "Human–Computer Interaction Institute") offers a master's degree in conjunction with the [University of Madeira](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Madeira "University of Madeira"), in Portugal at the jointly founded [Madeira Interactive Technologies Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madeira_Interactive_Technologies_Institute "Madeira Interactive Technologies Institute"). The College of Engineering has an international location in [Kigali, Rwanda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kigali,_Rwanda "Kigali, Rwanda") offering the Master of Science in Information Technology and the Master of Science in Electrical and Computer Engineering.

### Libraries

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Libraries")\]
