[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Hunt_Library_CMU_-_IMG_7844.JPG/250px-Hunt_Library_CMU_-_IMG_7844.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Hunt_Library_CMU_-_IMG_7844.JPG) Hunt Library is the largest library on Carnegie Mellon's Pittsburgh campus.

The Libraries of Carnegie Mellon include Hunt Library, the Roger Sorrells Engineering & Science Library, the [Mellon Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mellon_Institute "Mellon Institute") Library, the Posner Center, and the Qatar Library. Additionally, the Libraries' [Million Book Project](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Million_Book_Project "Million Book Project") (2001–2008) sparked development of the [Universal Digital Library](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_Digital_Library "Universal Digital Library"). The university libraries host a number of full text special collections for public access, including the [Andrew Carnegie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Carnegie "Andrew Carnegie") Collection, [Herbert A. Simon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbert_A._Simon "Herbert A. Simon") Collection, [Allen Newell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allen_Newell "Allen Newell") Collection, the [H. John Heinz III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H._John_Heinz_III "H. John Heinz III") Collection, the Pittsburgh Jewish Newspapers Project, and the Posner Memorial Collection. Carnegie Mellon students and faculty have access to the [Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Library_of_Pittsburgh "Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh") and some [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh") libraries through consortial agreements with those institutions. The [Hunt Institute for Botanical Documentation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunt_Institute_for_Botanical_Documentation "Hunt Institute for Botanical Documentation") (HIBD),[\[128\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-128) dedicated as the Rachel McMasters Miller Hunt Botanical Library in 1961, has been a research division of CMU since its founding. The HIBD is an international bibliographical research and service in the fields of botany, horticulture, and the history of the plant sciences and has a significant research library and art holdings on the 5th floor of Hunt Library. The university's [Software Engineering Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_Engineering_Institute "Software Engineering Institute") also houses a research library.

Carnegie Mellon also manages the [Naval Reserve Officer Training Corps](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naval_Reserve_Officer_Training_Corps "Naval Reserve Officer Training Corps") in Pittsburgh on which students throughout Pittsburgh's universities rely. Carnegie Mellon partners with the [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh") to provide opportunities in [Army Reserve Officers' Training Corps](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Army_Reserve_Officers%27_Training_Corps "Army Reserve Officers' Training Corps") and [Air Force Reserve Officer Training Corps](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_Force_Reserve_Officer_Training_Corps "Air Force Reserve Officer Training Corps") to its students.

Carnegie Mellon is accredited by the [Middle States Commission on Higher Education](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_States_Commission_on_Higher_Education "Middle States Commission on Higher Education").[\[129\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-129)

### Collaboration with the University of Pittsburgh

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Collaboration with the University of Pittsburgh")\]

Carnegie Mellon neighbors the campus of the [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh"), and in some cases, buildings of the two universities are intermingled. This helps to facilitate myriad academic and research collaborations between the two schools,[\[130\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-130) including such projects as the [Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Supercomputing_Center "Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center"), the [Pittsburgh Life Sciences Greenhouse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Life_Sciences_Greenhouse "Pittsburgh Life Sciences Greenhouse"), the Immune Modeling Center, the Center for the Neural Basis of Cognition, the [University of Pittsburgh Cancer Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh_Cancer_Institute "University of Pittsburgh Cancer Institute"), as well as the National Science Foundation-supported Pittsburgh Science of Learning Center.[\[131\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-131)[\[132\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-132) Further, the universities also offer multiple dual and joint degree programs such as the [Medical Scientist Training Program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh_School_of_Medicine#MD/PhD_Program "University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine"), the Molecular Biophysics and Structural Biology Graduate Program, the [Joint CMU-Pitt Ph.D. Program in Computational Biology](http://www.compbio.cmu.edu/), the [Center for Neural Basis of Cognition](http://www.cnbc.cmu.edu/), and the Law and Business Administration program. Some professors hold joint professorships between the two schools, and students at each university may take classes at the other (with appropriate approvals).[\[133\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-PCHE_Cross_Registration-133) CMU students and faculty also have access to the University of Pittsburgh library system, as well as the [Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Library_of_Pittsburgh "Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh"). The two universities also co-host academic conferences, such as the 2012 Second Language Research Forum.[\[134\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-134) In 2015, in conjunction with the University of Pittsburgh and [UPMC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh_Medical_Center "University of Pittsburgh Medical Center"), Carnegie Mellon became a partner of the Pittsburgh Health Data Alliance to leverage data analysis in health care.[\[135\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-135)

## Discoveries and innovation

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Discoveries and innovation")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Unix_history-simple.svg/250px-Unix_history-simple.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Unix_history-simple.svg) Simplified evolution of [Unix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix "Unix") systems. The [Mach kernel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mach_(kernel) "Mach (kernel)") was a fork from [BSD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BSD "BSD") 4.3 that led to [NeXTSTEP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NeXTSTEP "NeXTSTEP") / [OPENSTEP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OPENSTEP "OPENSTEP"), upon which [macOS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MacOS "MacOS") and [iOS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IOS "IOS") is based.

### Natural sciences

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Natural sciences")\]

- [Electron diffraction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electron_diffraction "Electron diffraction") – [Clinton Davisson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clinton_Davisson "Clinton Davisson") won the 1937 Nobel Prize in Physics for his discovery of electron diffraction in the famous [Davisson–Germer experiment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davisson%E2%80%93Germer_experiment "Davisson–Germer experiment"), which confirmed the [de Broglie hypothesis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Broglie_hypothesis "De Broglie hypothesis") that particles of matter have a wave-like nature, which is a central tenet of [quantum mechanics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_mechanics "Quantum mechanics"). In particular, their observation of diffraction allowed the first measurement of a [wavelength](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavelength "Wavelength") for [electrons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrons "Electrons").
- [Kevlar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevlar "Kevlar") – Developed by [Stephanie Kwolek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephanie_Kwolek "Stephanie Kwolek") at [DuPont](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DuPont "DuPont") in 1965, the high-strength material was first used commercially in the early 1970s as a replacement for steel in racing tires. Kevlar has many applications, ranging from bicycle tires and racing sails to bulletproof vests, all due to its high tensile strength-to-weight ratio; by this measure, it is five times stronger than steel.
- [Spectroscopy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectroscopy "Spectroscopy") – [John L. Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_L._Hall "John L. Hall") won the 2005 Nobel Prize in Physics with [Theodor W. Hänsch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theodor_W._H%C3%A4nsch "Theodor W. Hänsch") and [Roy J. Glauber](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roy_J._Glauber "Roy J. Glauber") for his pioneering work on laser-based precision spectroscopy and the optical [frequency comb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frequency_comb "Frequency comb") technique.
- [Neutron scattering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neutron_scattering "Neutron scattering") – [Clifford G. Shull](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clifford_G._Shull "Clifford G. Shull") was awarded the 1994 Nobel Prize in Physics with Canadian [Bertram Brockhouse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bertram_Brockhouse "Bertram Brockhouse") for their pioneering work in neutron scattering, a technique that reveals where atoms are within a material like ricocheting bullets reveal where obstacles are in the dark.

### Computer and applied sciences

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Computer and applied sciences")\]

- [Alice (software)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alice_(software) "Alice (software)") – [freeware](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freeware "Freeware") (for non-commercial purposes) [object-based](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object-based_language "Object-based language") [educational programming language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Educational_programming_language "Educational programming language") with an [integrated development environment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrated_development_environment "Integrated development environment") (IDE).[\[136\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-136)
- [Andrew Project](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Project "Andrew Project") – [distributed computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_computing "Distributed computing") environment developed at Carnegie Mellon beginning in 1982. It was an ambitious project for its time and resulted in an unprecedentedly vast and accessible university computing infrastructure. The goal was to have connected [3M computer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3M_computer "3M computer") workstations.[\[137\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-cmu_overview-137)
- [Artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence "Artificial intelligence") – Several of the first AI software programs were created at Carnegie Mellon. These include the [Logic Theorist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_Theorist "Logic Theorist"), [General Problem Solver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Problem_Solver "General Problem Solver"), and [Soar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soar_(cognitive_architecture) "Soar (cognitive architecture)").
- [Autonomous vehicle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_vehicle "Autonomous vehicle") – [Navlab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navlab "Navlab"), the first [autonomous car](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_car "Autonomous car") program was developed by Carnegie Mellon. Since then, [H1ghlander](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H1ghlander "H1ghlander") and [Sandstorm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandstorm_(vehicle) "Sandstorm (vehicle)") autonomous vehicles were developed at Carnegie Mellon and placed 3rd and 2nd in the [DARPA Grand Challenge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DARPA_Grand_Challenge "DARPA Grand Challenge") and Carnegie Mellon's Boss won the [DARPA Grand Challenge (2007)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DARPA_Grand_Challenge_(2007) "DARPA Grand Challenge (2007)").[\[138\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-138) The university continues to be a leader in autonomous research and development.
- [Dynamic random-access memory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_random-access_memory "Dynamic random-access memory") – In 1966, [Robert H. Dennard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_H._Dennard "Robert H. Dennard") invented the one-transistor memory cell consisting of a transistor and a capacitor for which a patent was issued in 1968. It became the basis for today's dynamic random-access memory (DRAM).
- [MEMS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MEMS "MEMS") – [Harvey C. Nathanson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvey_C._Nathanson "Harvey C. Nathanson") invented the first MEMS (micro-electro-mechanical systems) device of the type now found in products ranging from iPhones to automobiles. Typical MEMS devices include the accelerometers found in smartphones and video game controllers, and the gyroscopes used in automobiles and wearables.
- [Xerox PARC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xerox_PARC "Xerox PARC") – Founded in 1969 by [George Pake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Pake "George Pake") and Jack Goldman, Xerox PARC has been at the heart of numerous revolutionary computer developments as laser printing, Ethernet, the modern personal computer, graphical user interface (GUI) and desktop paradigm, object-oriented programming, ubiquitous computing, electronic paper, amorphous silicon (a-Si) applications, the computer mouse, and advancing very-large-scale integration (VLSI) for semiconductors.
- [BLISS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BLISS "BLISS") – [system programming language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_programming_language "System programming language") developed at Carnegie Mellon by [W. A. Wulf](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/W._A._Wulf "W. A. Wulf"), [D. B. Russell](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=D._B._Russell&action=edit&redlink=1 "D. B. Russell (page does not exist)"), and [A. N. Habermann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A._N._Habermann "A. N. Habermann") around 1970. It was perhaps the best known systems programming language until [C](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C_(programming_language) "C (programming language)") made its debut in 1972.[\[139\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-139)
- [Emoticon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emoticon "Emoticon") – The first true emoticon was developed at Carnegie Mellon by [Scott Fahlman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Fahlman "Scott Fahlman") in 1982.
- [Hashtag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hashtag "Hashtag") – In a 2007 tweet, [Chris Messina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Messina_(open-source_advocate) "Chris Messina (open-source advocate)") proposed vertical/associational grouping of messages, trends, and events on [Twitter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter "Twitter") by the means of hashtags.
- [Java](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_(programming_language) "Java (programming language)") – [class-based](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Class-based "Class-based") [object oriented](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object-oriented_programming "Object-oriented programming") programming language that was originally developed by [James Gosling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Gosling "James Gosling") at [Sun Microsystems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sun_Microsystems "Sun Microsystems") (which has since been acquired by [Oracle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oracle_Corporation "Oracle Corporation")) and released in 1995 as a core component of Sun Microsystems' Java platform.
- [Mach (kernel)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mach_(kernel) "Mach (kernel)") – [Richard Rashid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Rashid "Richard Rashid") and [Avie Tevanian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avie_Tevanian "Avie Tevanian") developed Mach at Carnegie Mellon from 1985 to 1994, ending with Mach 3.0, which is a true [microkernel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microkernel "Microkernel"). Mach was developed as a replacement for the kernel in the [BSD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berkeley_Software_Distribution "Berkeley Software Distribution") version of [Unix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix "Unix"), so no new operating system would have to be designed around it. Experimental research on Mach appears to have ended, although Mach and its derivatives exist within a number of commercial operating systems. These include [NeXTSTEP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NeXTSTEP "NeXTSTEP") and [OPENSTEP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OPENSTEP "OPENSTEP"), upon which [macOS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MacOS "MacOS") and [iOS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IOS "IOS") are based.[\[140\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-140)
- [Wi-Fi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wi-Fi "Wi-Fi") network – Alex Hills created the first wi-fi network using a [local area network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_area_network "Local area network") (LAN) on the Carnegie Mellon campus in 1993.[\[141\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-141)[\[142\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-142)

### Companies and entrepreneurship

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Companies and entrepreneurship")\]

[The Swartz Center for Entrepreneurship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swartz_Center_for_Entrepreneurship "Swartz Center for Entrepreneurship") acts as Carnegie Mellon's [startup accelerator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Startup_accelerator "Startup accelerator"). Jim Swartz, co-founder of [Accel Partners](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accel_Partners "Accel Partners"), pledged $31 Million to establish a hub for university wide entrepreneurial activities. His gift is the fifth largest Carnegie Mellon has received. In 2016, the center opened providing a [business incubator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Business_incubator "Business incubator") and [makerspace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Makerspace "Makerspace").[\[143\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-143) The center employs [Entrepreneurs-in-Residence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entrepreneur_in_residence "Entrepreneur in residence") who mentor founders of early stage companies consisting of students, faculty, and alumni.[\[144\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-144) Startups work on their ideas throughout the year culminating at an annual Demo Day where they showcase their company to the public.[\[145\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-145)

## Student life

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Student life")\]

Student body composition as of May 2, 2022
hide

Carnegie Mellon's student life includes over 400 student organizations, art galleries, and various unique traditions. Student organizations provide social, service, media, academic, spiritual, recreational, sport, religious, political, cultural, and governance opportunities. Carnegie Mellon's campus houses several galleries such as _The Frame_, a student-devoted gallery, and the [Regina Gouger Miller Gallery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regina_Gouger_Miller_Gallery "Regina Gouger Miller Gallery"), an art gallery that specializes in contemporary professional artists. The [Carnegie Mellon School of Music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_School_of_Music "Carnegie Mellon School of Music"), [Carnegie Mellon School of Drama](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_School_of_Drama "Carnegie Mellon School of Drama"), and the student-run theatrical organization [Scotch'n'Soda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scotch%27n%27Soda "Scotch'n'Soda") provides campus with a variety of performance arts events. The university has a strong Scottish motif inspired by Andrew Carnegie's Scottish heritage, as well as the Mellon family's Scots-Irish ancestry. Examples include Scotty, the [Scottish Terrier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scottish_Terrier "Scottish Terrier") mascot, _[The Tartan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Tartan_(Carnegie_Mellon_University) "The Tartan (Carnegie Mellon University)")_ student newspaper, [Skibo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skibo_Castle "Skibo Castle") Gymnasium, The [Thistle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thistle "Thistle") yearbook, and the [Céilidh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C%C3%A9ilidh "Céilidh") weekend every fall semester for homecoming.[\[149\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-152)

### Housing

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Housing")\]

Carnegie Mellon offers conventional housing for its students through single-gender, coresidential, and special interest options. Students can choose from a variety of housing options. The four options for students are traditional, semi-suite, suite, and apartments. The Traditional is a typical college dormitory setting, a long hallway with a series of 1-3 person rooms and a community bathroom shared with an entire floor or wing. Semi-Suite offers more privacy through 1-4 person rooms with 3-5 residents sharing one semi-private bathroom. Suite is similar to Semi-Suite but contains additional bedrooms, a bathroom, and living room/lounge area shared with 3-8 other residents. Apartments are shared between 1-3 people and may contain additional bedrooms, a semi-private bathroom, a living room, and kitchen shared with the other residents. Upperclassmen have additional options for housing, which include town houses and a larger variety of one or two bedroom apartments.[\[150\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-153) There are 27 residential buildings on campus and even more off campus.[\[151\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-154)

First-year students are assigned to the dedicated first-year residence halls on campus including Morewood E-Tower, Morewood Gardens, Residence on Fifth, Shirley Apartments, as well as Boss, Donner, Hamerschlag, McGill, Mudge, Scobell, and Stever Houses. Approximately one-third of upperclassmen choose to continue living on campus through university housing. Options for upperclassmen include Fifth & Clyde, Morewood Gardens, West Wing, Doherty, Fairfax, Margaret Morrison, Fifth Neville, Shady Oak, Shirley, Forbes & Beeler, and Woodlawn Apartments as well as Henderson, Resnik, Roselawn, Spirit, Tech, Webster, and Welch Houses.[\[152\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-CMU_Housing-155)

The Greek tradition at Carnegie Mellon began over 100 years ago with the founding of the first fraternity on campus, [Theta Xi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theta_Xi "Theta Xi"), in 1912.[\[153\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-156)

### Specialized communities

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Specialized communities")\]

In 2022, Welch House began to host the specialized Queer community, a living community suited to the needs of [non-binary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-binary "Non-binary") students by allowing students to "live in the same room with any other student inclusive of sex assigned at birth, gender identity, gender expression, and/or sexual orientation".[\[154\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-157) Welch House consists of semi-suite singles and doubles. In addition, Stever House hosts an all-gender floor for students who would prefer a traditional double.

Spirit House is a residential community for upperclassmen designated for members of the SPIRIT student organization, a Black Student Union that serves as a haven for Black students within the Carnegie Mellon community and champions issues facing the Black community.
[\[155\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-158)

### Traditions

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Traditions")\]

Main article: [Carnegie Mellon University traditions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University_traditions "Carnegie Mellon University traditions")

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/The_Fence_at_Carnegie_Mellon_University.jpg/250px-The_Fence_at_Carnegie_Mellon_University.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:The_Fence_at_Carnegie_Mellon_University.jpg) The Fence

In the early days of Carnegie Tech, there was a single bridge connecting Margaret Morrison Women's College with the Carnegie Institute of Technology. The bridge was a meeting place for students. In 1916, the bridge was taken down and the university filled in the area. The administration built a wooden fence as a new meeting place. The students did not understand why anyone would want to meet at a fence. The administration was about to give up and tear it down, but that night a fraternity, as a prank, painted the entire fence advertising a fraternity party. Ever since, painting the Fence has been a Carnegie Mellon tradition.[\[156\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-159) The Fence at Carnegie Mellon lies at the center of campus, in the area known as "the Cut". Students guard the fence 24 hours a day, and, as long as two vigils are maintained, no other student may "take" the fence. The fence can then be painted by the group that has it, but only between midnight and 6 am. Only hand brushes may be used; the use of spray paint or paint rollers is considered vandalism and results in a fine. The previous paint cannot be stripped, and each new painting adds a new layer. The original wooden fence finally collapsed in the 1990s due to the weight from over 1' of surrounding paint, and was immediately replaced with an identical one manufactured from concrete. Today the fence is considered "the world's most painted object" by the _[Guinness Book of World Records](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guinness_Book_of_World_Records "Guinness Book of World Records")_.[\[157\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-160)

## Athletics

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Athletics")\]

The Carnegie Mellon Tartans were a founding member of the [University Athletic Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_Athletic_Association "University Athletic Association") of [NCAA Division III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Division_III_(NCAA) "Division III (NCAA)"). Prior to World War II, Carnegie Mellon (as Carnegie Tech) played with what are now classified as [NCAA Division I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NCAA_Division_I "NCAA Division I") teams. In 1936, the Carnegie Tech riflery team won the national intercollegiate championship.[\[158\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-161) The Carnegie Tech men's basketball team was a member of the [Eastern Intercollegiate Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_Intercollegiate_Conference "Eastern Intercollegiate Conference") throughout the conference's existence from 1932 to 1939[\[159\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-162) and won the conference championship in 1936, defeating [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Panthers_men%27s_basketball "Pittsburgh Panthers men's basketball") in a conference championship playoff game.[\[160\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-163)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/CMU_Tennis_Courts.jpg/250px-CMU_Tennis_Courts.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:CMU_Tennis_Courts.jpg) Carnegie Mellon [tennis courts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_court "Tennis court")

Varsity teams are fielded in basketball, track, cross country, football, golf, soccer, swimming and diving, volleyball, tennis, and softball. In addition, club teams exist in [ultimate frisbee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultimate_frisbee "Ultimate frisbee"),[\[161\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-164) [rowing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rowing_(sport) "Rowing (sport)"),[\[162\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-165) [rugby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rugby_football "Rugby football"), lacrosse, hockey,[\[163\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-166) baseball,[\[164\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-167) softball, [skiing & snowboarding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alpine_skiing "Alpine skiing"),[\[165\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-168) soccer, volleyball, water polo,[\[166\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-169) and cycling.[\[167\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-170) Carnegie Mellon Athletics runs a comprehensive and popular intramural system, maintains facilities (primarily Skibo Gymnasium, Cohon University Center, Gesling Stadium, and the future Highmark Center for Health, Wellness and Athletics), and offers courses to students in fitness and sports. Carnegie Mellon's primary athletic rivals are fellow [UAA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_Athletic_Association "University Athletic Association") schools [Case Western Reserve University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_Western_Reserve_Spartans "Case Western Reserve Spartans") and [Washington University in St. Louis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_University_Bears "Washington University Bears"); the Tartans had an especially intense rivalry with the [latter's football team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_University_Bears_football "Washington University Bears football") from the 2000s to 2017.

### Football

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Football")\]

Main article: [Carnegie Mellon Tartans football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_Tartans_football "Carnegie Mellon Tartans football")

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Football_at_Carnegie_Mellon.jpg/250px-Football_at_Carnegie_Mellon.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Football_at_Carnegie_Mellon.jpg) Football at Gesling Stadium

On November 28, 1926, the 6–2 Carnegie Technical Institute football team shut out the undefeated [Notre Dame Fighting Irish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Notre_Dame_Fighting_Irish_football "Notre Dame Fighting Irish football") 19–0 at [Forbes Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes_Field "Forbes Field"). [Knute Rockne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knute_Rockne "Knute Rockne"), the coach of the Irish at the time, was so confident that the Irish would defeat "tiny Carnegie Tech" that he decided to skip the game and travel to Chicago to watch the Army-Navy football game for scouting purposes. It was only later that he found out by telegram that the Irish had suffered their first loss of the season. ESPN compared the upset to the Appalachian State victory over the University of Michigan in 2007.[\[168\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-171) The game was ranked the fourth-greatest upset in [college football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/College_football "College football") history by [ESPN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN "ESPN").[\[169\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-172)

Since 2025, the Tartans play in the [Centennial Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centennial_Conference "Centennial Conference") at the [NCAA Division III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NCAA_Division_III "NCAA Division III") level. The head coach of the football team is [Ryan Larsen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryan_Larsen "Ryan Larsen"), who was the [Presidents' Athletic Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidents%27_Athletic_Conference "Presidents' Athletic Conference") coach of the year in 2022. Prior to losing in the Sweet 16 of the 2022 D3 playoffs, the Tartans held a 17-game win streak which was, at the time, the longest win streak across all NCAA divisions in football.

### Track and cross country

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Track and cross country")\]

In recent years, the varsity track and [cross country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross_country_running "Cross country running") programs have seen outstanding success on the [Division III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Division_III_(NCAA) "Division III (NCAA)") national level. The men's cross country team has finished in the top 15 in the nation each of the last three years, and has boasted several individual [All-Americans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/All-America "All-America"). The men's track team has also boasted several individual All-Americans spanning sprinting, distance, and field disciplines. Recent All-Americans from the track team are Bram Miller (2021), Tommy Vandenberg (2014–2015), Brian Harvey (2007–2009), [Davey Quinn](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Davey_Quinn&action=edit&redlink=1 "Davey Quinn (page does not exist)") (2007), [Nik Bonaddio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nik_Bonaddio "Nik Bonaddio") (2004, 2005), Mark Davis (2004, 2005), Russel Verbofsky (2004, 2005) and Kiley Williams.[\[170\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-173) Carolyn Lowe (10,000 meters 1992) is the only track athlete to win an NCAA Division III championship.

### Volleyball

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Volleyball")\]

With much of the team's support, Lauren Schmidt received the NCAA Pennsylvania Woman of the Year award (2003), was a two-time All-American (2001 and 2002), a four-time All-University Athletic Association selection (1999–2002), and the conference's Player of the Year (2001).[\[171\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-174)

### Intramurals

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Intramurals")\]

Students can participate in any level of competition across multiple sports including [wiffle ball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wiffle_ball "Wiffle ball"), [dodgeball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dodgeball "Dodgeball"), [basketball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basketball "Basketball"), [flag football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_football "Flag football"), [ultimate frisbee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultimate_(sport) "Ultimate (sport)") and many more.[\[172\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-175)

## Alumni and faculty

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Alumni and faculty")\]

Main article: [List of Carnegie Mellon University people](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Carnegie_Mellon_University_people "List of Carnegie Mellon University people")

There are more than 117,000 Carnegie Mellon alumni worldwide with the graduating class of 2022.[\[173\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-:3-176) Alumni and current/former faculty include 21 [Nobel laureates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nobel_laureates "Nobel laureates"), six members of the [National Academy of Medicine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Academy_of_Medicine "National Academy of Medicine"), 22 members of the [National Academy of Sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Academy_of_Sciences "National Academy of Sciences"), 72 members of the [National Academy of Engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Academy_of_Engineering "National Academy of Engineering"), two [MacArthur Fellows](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MacArthur_Fellows_Program "MacArthur Fellows Program"), 24 [Guggenheim Fellows](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guggenheim_Fellowship "Guggenheim Fellowship"), seven [Packard fellows](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_and_Lucile_Packard_Foundation "David and Lucile Packard Foundation"), 142 [Emmy Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emmy_Award "Emmy Award") recipients (including ten time recipient [Steven Bochco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steven_Bochco "Steven Bochco")), 12 [Academy Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academy_Award "Academy Award") recipients, 52 [Tony Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Award "Tony Award") recipients, two winners of the [Stockholm Prize in Criminology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stockholm_Prize_in_Criminology "Stockholm Prize in Criminology"), and 13 [Turing Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turing_Award "Turing Award") recipients.[\[174\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-:0-177)

## In popular culture

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: In popular culture")\]

The campus of Carnegie Mellon in Pittsburgh has served as the locale for many motion pictures. Alumnus [George A. Romero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_A._Romero "George A. Romero") filmed _[Creepshow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Creepshow "Creepshow")_ (1982) in and around Margaret Morrison Carnegie Hall.[\[185\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-188) Much of the on-campus scenes in the 2000 film _[Wonder Boys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wonder_Boys_(film) "Wonder Boys (film)")_, starring [Michael Douglas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Douglas "Michael Douglas") and [Tobey Maguire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tobey_Maguire "Tobey Maguire"), were filmed in Carnegie Mellon's campus.[\[186\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-189) Other movies filmed at Carnegie Mellon include _[The Mothman Prophecies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Mothman_Prophecies_(film) "The Mothman Prophecies (film)")_, _[Dogma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dogma_(film) "Dogma (film)")_, _[Lorenzo's Oil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lorenzo%27s_Oil "Lorenzo's Oil")_, _[Hoffa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hoffa_(film) "Hoffa (film)")_, _[The Dark Knight Rises](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Dark_Knight_Rises "The Dark Knight Rises")_, _[Where'd You Go, Bernadette](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Where%27d_You_Go,_Bernadette_(film) "Where'd You Go, Bernadette (film)")_, and _[Flashdance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flashdance "Flashdance")_. The university is also featured prominently in the films _[Smart People](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smart_People "Smart People")_, _[Monkey Shines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monkey_Shines_(film) "Monkey Shines (film)")_, and in the anime _[Summer Wars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Summer_Wars "Summer Wars")_.

The musical _[Pippin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pippin_(musical) "Pippin (musical)")_ was originally conceived by [Stephen Schwartz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Schwartz_(composer) "Stephen Schwartz (composer)") as a student musical performed by the [Scotch'n'Soda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scotch%27n%27Soda "Scotch'n'Soda") student theatre troupe.[\[187\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-190) Schwartz also collaborated with drama student [John-Michael Tebelak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John-Michael_Tebelak "John-Michael Tebelak") to expand his master's thesis project titled _[Godspell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Godspell "Godspell")_, created under the direction of [Lawrence Carra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawrence_Carra "Lawrence Carra"), into a musical.[\[188\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-191)

While enrolled at Carnegie Mellon, acting students [Michael McKean](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_McKean "Michael McKean") and [David Lander](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Lander "David Lander") (class of 1969) created the characters "Lenny and Squiggy".[\[189\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-192) The pair continued performing the characters in live comedy routines before joining the cast of the TV series _[Laverne & Shirley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laverne_%26_Shirley "Laverne & Shirley")_.

In 2008, Carnegie Mellon professor [Randy Pausch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randy_Pausch "Randy Pausch")'s " [Last Lecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Really_Achieving_Your_Childhood_Dreams "Really Achieving Your Childhood Dreams")" became a pop culture phenomenon. Based on a lecture he gave in September 2007 – shortly after he learned his cancer had metastasized – his book quickly rose to the top of bestseller lists around the country. Named in _[Time](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_(magazine) "Time (magazine)")_ magazine's [_Time_ 100](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_100 "Time 100") list of influential people, he died in July 2008 from pancreatic cancer.[\[190\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-193)

In 2003, Carnegie Mellon established the [Robot Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_Hall_of_Fame "Robot Hall of Fame") in partnership with the [Carnegie Science Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Science_Center "Carnegie Science Center").

The [68th Tony Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/68th_Tony_Awards "68th Tony Awards") in 2014 announced Carnegie Mellon as its first educational partner in jointly awarding the "Tony Honor for Excellence in Theatre Education", which will "honor kindergarten through high school (K-12) theatre educators".[\[191\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-194)
